Award.AwardTitle: Structure and Properties of the Twist-Bend Nematic Phase
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT.

Liquid crystals brought a revolution in how we present information nowadays, enabling the entire industry of Liquid Crystal Displays (LCDs). Modern devices ranging from smart phones to laptop screens and flat-panel TV sets are all featuring the LCDs, in which so-called nematic liquid crystals realign under the action of the electric field, thus changing the optical appearance of the pixelated screen. For many years, the only known type of nematic alignment was the one with a single straight axis of molecular orientation. This project focuses on a newly discovered nematic order, in which the molecular orientation follows a nontrivial geometry of an oblique helicoid, with twists and bends at a very small scale of nanometers. The project will establish the basic properties of the new nematic liquid crystals, determine their structure and properties and explore how the new materials can be used in practical applications such as LCDs.

TECHNICAL ABSTRACT.

Liquid crystals (LCs) represent a peculiar state of matter combining properties of solid crystals and isotropic fluids. The most widely known type of LCs is the so-called nematic, in which rod-like molecules are aligned parallel to each other, but have the freedom to glide past their neighbors. The subtle combination of order, fluidity, and eager responsiveness to the electric field featured by the nematics brought a revolution in the way we present information nowadays, enabling an entire industry of portable LC displays, or LCDs. For many decades, the single axis of molecular orientation, the so-called director, was considered as the only possible nematic made of non-chiral molecules. Theoretical models by Meyer and Dozov hypothesized, however, that there might be nematics in which the director bends and twists. In 2013, the existence of the twist-bend nematic Ntb was proven in materials with dimeric molecules, representing two rigid cores connected by a flexible aliphatic chain. In Ntb, the ground-state director is not a straight line, but follows an oblique helicoid with a nanoscale pitch. The goal of this project is to explore the detailed structural and physical properties of Ntb. The nanoscale-modulated director should be sensitive to weak driving forces such as temperature and electric field, promising applications that might rival those of the classic LCs. The project will establish a fundamental understanding of the Ntb structure with spontaneously broken chiral symmetry at the widely disparate length scales from nanometers to hundreds of microns and determine the physical properties of materials forming Ntb, such as elasticity and responsiveness to electromagnetic fields. The goals will be achieved by applying a battery of imaging and characterization techniques, ranging from cryo-TEM to 3D optical microscopy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Liquid crystals (LCs) represent a peculiar state of matter combining properties of solid crystals and isotropic fluids.  The most widely known type of LCs is the so-called nematic, in which rod-like molecules are aligned parallel to each other, but have the freedom to glide past their neighbors.  The subtle combination of order, fluidity, and eager responsiveness to the electric field featured by the nematics brought a revolution in the way we present information nowadays, enabling an entire industry of portable LC displays, or LCDs.  For many decades, the single axis of molecular orientation, the so-called director, was considered as the only possible nematic made of non-chiral molecules.  Theoretical models by Meyer and Dozov hypothesized, however, that there might be nematics in which the director bends and twists.  In 2013, the existence of the twist-bend nematic has been proven in materials with dimeric molecules, representing two rigid cores connected by a flexible aliphatic chain.  The research goals of the project were (1) to establish a fundamental understanding of the twist-bend structures at the widely disparate length scales from nanometers to hundreds of microns; (2) to determine the physical properties of materials forming twist-bend structures, such as elasticity and responsiveness to electromagnetic fields; (3) to explore non-traditional dimers such as hydrogen-bond dimers and azobenzene-based dimers can form twist-bend structures.  The tasks were addressed by applying a battery of imaging and characterization techniques, ranging from cryo-TEM to three-dimensional optical microscopy, and by using the PI experience in exploring elastic, surface, and electro-optical properties of LCs. 

The most important outcome in terms of the intellectual merit of the project was an experimental discovery that the dimeric nematic materials, when doped with a small amount of the chiral molecules, can form a cholesteric state with an oblique helicoidal alignment of molecules when acted upon by the electric or magnetic field. In the conventional cholesteric liquid crystals, the molecules twist in space along a right-angle helicoidal structure, being everywhere perpendicular to the helicoidal axis.  In the discovered cholesteric state formed by dimers, the molecules twist and bend in space, being tilted with respect to the helicoidal axis (rather than perpendicular to it).  This structural difference brings an important distinction in electric and magnetic response. Namely, the externally applied field can be used to smoothly tune the period of the structure without changing its single-mode sinusoidal geometry.  If the material is designed to have its period in a sub-micrometer range, this tuning results in a spectacular effect of changing structural colors of the material in a very broad range from ultraviolet to infrared, including the entire visible part of spectrum.  The project also established the material properties of the dimeric materials and contrasted them to the properties of their monomeric analogs. In particular, the bend elastic constants were measured to be many times smaller in the dimeric materials as compared to the monomeric ones.  This feature was demonstrated to be responsible for the formation of the oblique helicoidal cholesterics.  Other findings include discovery of a photo-controllable twist-bend nematic phase in azobenzene derivatives and in dimers with asymmetric arms.

This newly discovered electro-optical response of liquid crystals requires no polarizers and thus can be used in a wide range of practical applications, including tunable optical filters, polarizers-free displays, smart windows and also in tunable lasers, thus demonstrating a broader impact of the project.  The project helped to educate graduate students in the field of optics and physics of complex materials with chiral symmetry.  The transformative value of the project was in finding the new concept of materials design built on the twist-bend arrangements of organic molecules.
